div1.p: This is a Cuban Treasury Deposit receipt for the expenses of the Yellow Fever experiments at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Receipt for Disbursing Officer's Credit, November 15, 1900

FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
Synopsis of Instructions relative to Revenue Funds of Cuba and Official Checks
of Disbursing Officers.
Any revenues of the Island of Cuba advanced to disbursing officers must be deposited immediately to their
respective credits with the designated Depositary nearest or most convenient, except-
(1.) Any disbursing officer stationed at a place remote from such depositary, may, when authorized by the
Division Commander, keep at his own risk such money as may be entrusted to him for disbursement.
(2.) Any disbursing officer receiving money upon specific estimates may disburse it in accordance therewith,
without placing it in a depositary, provided the payments are due.
Each official check drawn by a disbursing officer must state the object or purpose to which the funds are to be
applied.
Such statements may be made in brief from but must clearly indicate the object of the expenditure, i.e: “Pay-
roll,” adding the place: “on contract for construction,” naming the work for which the payment is made, etc.
Checks will not be returned to the drawer after their payment, but the depositary shall furnish the officer with
a monthly statement of his account.
No allowance will be made to any disbursing officer for expenses charged for collecting money on checks.
If a disbursing officer dies, resigns, or is relieved, checks previously drawn by him will be paid from the funds
to his credit, unless such checks have been drawn more than four months before their presentation, or fraud is
suspected.
Every disbursing officer when opening his first account will furnish the depositary on whom checks are drawn,
with his official signature duly verified by some officer whose signature is known to the depositary.
Any official check drawn by a disbursing officer must be in favor of the party by name to whom the payment is
to be made, and payable to “order” or “bearer” except in the following cases:
(1) To make payment of amounts not exceeding $20.00.
(2) To make payment at a distance from the depositary, and for the satisfaction of pay-rolls; in either of which
case the disbursing officer may draw his check in favor of himself for such amount as may be necessary, but, as far as
possible these checks should be made to cover the exact amount of the payment in each case.
This receipt to be issued in duplicate, one copy to be sent to the party making the deposit, and the other to be
sent to the party whose account is to receive the credit.
